the central cell and one side of the circumambient; the
formation of the first three zones, <u>a</u>-<u>b</u>, on the simple type;
the imperfect separation of the superficial cells from the
intermediate stratum in the next two zones, <u>b-c</u>, <s>on the
complex type, and</s> the regular development of the re-
mainder, c-d, on the complex type:- 50 diam.

                 Plate VIII
Figs. 1-8. Various examples of the <u>Reparation</u>
of disks after fracture, and of the growth of
new disks from detached fragments. For des-
cription, see Par. 37-40 of Memoir - Figs 3 & 5 are mag-
nified 12 diam: the rest 35 diam.

              Plate IX
Figs. 1-12. A series of specimens, drawn under the
same magnifying power, illustrating the extreme
<u>variations</u> which present themselves in regard to
Size, with the intervening links of connection.
Nos 1,2,3,4,5,10,12 represent entire specimens; whilst
6,7,8,9,11 are the central portions of larger disks. No. 5
represents the specimen from which, viewed under
transmitted light, Plate II, Fig. 2 is taken:- 35 diam.
